questions.text: In case of vesicoureteric reflux which will be investigation of choice: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Option A is correct as micturating cystourethrogram can pick up reflux of urine into the ureter during the act of micturition as the pressure in the urinary bladder rises Option B is good for any anatomy of the urogenital tract with respect to hydronephrosis or dilated pelvicalyceal system. It is not useful in detecting VUR. Option C that is cystography is the study done in urinary bladder which maps the pressure changes in the bladder during micturition and can give the idea of bladder outlet obstruction. Option D that is radionuclide scan is used for detecting the static and dynamic component of the kidney function and detects hydronephrosis and renal scarring.

questions.text: In a patient suspected to be suffering from vesicoureteric reflux, which one of the following radiological investigations may confirm the diagnosis? (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Option B is correct as micturating cystourethrogram can pick up reflux of urine into the ureter during the act of micturition as the pressure in the urinary bladder rises MCU Grading of VUR Grade I: Reflux into non dilated ureter Grade II: Reflux into pelvis and calyces without dilation Grade III: Mild to moderate dilation of the ureter, renal pelvis and calyces with minimal blunting of the fornices Grade IV: Dilation of the pelvis and calyces with blunting. Grade V: Gross dilation of the ureter, pelvis and calyces; loss of papillary impression and ureteral tortuosity

questions.text: Reflux filling the pelvicalyceal system without dilatation: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) MCU Grading of VUR Grade I: Reflux into non dilated ureter Grade II: Reflux into pelvis and calyces without dilation Grade III: Mild to moderate dilation of the ureter, renal pelvis and calyces with minimal blunting of the fornices Grade IV: Dilation of the pelvis and calyces with blunting. Grade V: Gross dilation of the ureter, pelvis and calyces; loss of papillary impression and ureteral tortuosity

questions.text: Spontaneous resolution of VUR depends on: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Spontaneous resolution of VUR depends upon the grade of reflux and the age of presentation. With bladder growth and maturation, most low-grade reflux resolves spontaneously. Severe grades of reflux are less likely to resolve. Mean age of reflux resolution is 6-7 years

choices.text: Renal scarring usually begins in the midpolar regions
Postnatal scarring may occur even in the absence of urinary tract infections
Long-term outcome is comparable in patients treated with either antibiotic prophylaxis or surgery
Oral amoxicillin is the choice antibiotic for prophylaxis

questions.text: Which of the following statements are true for primary grade IV-V vesicoureteric reflux in young children? (AIIMS May 2015)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Although UTI is the most important cause for scarring and nephropathy in patients with VUR, scarring can occur even in the absence of UTI due to pressure effect of reflux on the renal tissue. Option C is wrong as the long term outcomes are better in patients who have undergone surgical intervention as compared to antibiotic prophylaxis. Option D is wrong as amoxicillin and ampicillin is used only in those patients who are less than 6 weeks. If the child is more than 6 weeks antibiotic of choice for prophylaxis is trimethoprim sulphamethoxazole.

questions.text: While treating ectopia vesicae, bone divided is: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) While treating ectopia vesicae we subject the patient to posterior iliac bone osteomy to facilitate the mobilisation of the bladder and facilitate urinary bladder closure. We do not do pubic bone, sacrum and coccyx bone osteotomy while treating ectopia vesicae.

questions.text: Ectopic vesicae includes all except: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Hypospadias is not a component of ectopia vesicae, Ectopia vesicae is associated with epispadias and is referred to as ectopia vesicae epispadias complex. Extrophy of bladder is complete ventral defect of urogenital sinus and the overlying skeletal system. Defect in the infraumbilical part of the anterior abdominal wall, associated with incomplete development of the anterior wall of the bladder.

questions.text: About ectopia vesicae, following is true except: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) In ectopia vesicae we have dorsal curvature of penis with epispadias . Option A is correct as ectopia vesicae predisposes patients to suffer from adenocarcinoma of bladder. Option D is correct as in ectopia vesicae we have the wall of the bladder fused with skin, there is absent anterior wall of the bladder and ureters open on to the exposed bladder with urine dribbling over abdominal cavity.

questions.text: What is Marion’s disease? (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Marion's disease is obstruction of the outlet of the bladder caused by enlargement of the muscle cells in the neck of the bladder. Marion described a series of cases in which muscular hypertrophy of the internal sphincter in a young person had resulted in the development of a vesical diverticulum or hydronephrosis (Marion’s disease). It is thought that dyssynergic contraction of the smooth muscle of the bladder neck (bladder neck dyssynergia) may account for some cases of BOO.

choices.text: Flap of the bladder wall fashioned into a tube to replace lower ureter

questions.text: What is Boari's flap surgery? (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Option A that is ureteroureterostomy is an option we have for ureteric injury treatment but it is not the same as boari’s flap repair. Option B that is DJ stent in situ has nothing to be do with boari’s flap. Option C that is bowel interposition is also one of the options for repair of ureter after ureteric injury but it is not called as boari’s flap.

questions.text: Interstitial cystitis is also known as: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Hunner`s cystitis is another name of interstitial cystitis and is characterised by multiple linear bleeding ulcers on the dome of the bladder and the cause is infiltration by lymphocytes. Eosinophilic cystitis (EC) is a rare clinicopathological condition characterized by transmural inflammation of the bladder predominantly with eosinophils, associated with fibrosis with or without muscle necrosis. Radiation Cystitis is a term used to describe the side effect of inflammation and subsequent destruction to the normal anatomy of the urinary bladder at the cellular level after the use of radiation in the treatment of multiple cancer types, including, most commonly, pelvic cancers Tuberculous Cystitis : Up to 10% of patients with renal TB have bladder contractures.

choices.text: Common in pediatric patients in the tropics than in non-tropical areas.
Uric acid stones are dropped from above.
Jack stones are caused by a urinary tract infection with urea-splitting bacteria.
The most common cause of stone formation is distal passage obstruction.

questions.text: Regarding urinary bladder stones, which of the following statements is false?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) A. Common in pediatric patients in the tropics than in non-tropical areas. True. Primary bladder stones (those not caused by obstruction) are more common in children in tropical regions due to factors like diet and dehydration. B. Uric acid stones are dropped from above. False. Uric acid stones are the most common type of primary bladder stones. They form directly in the bladder and are not caused by an obstruction or infection. Stones that "drop from above" are typically kidney stones that pass into the bladder. C. Jack stones are caused by a urinary tract infection with urea-splitting bacteria. True. Jack stones are a type of calcium oxalate stone that gets its name from its appearance. They can be caused by infections with urea-splitting bacteria. This is a correct statement, but it is often confused with struvite stones, which are also caused by urea-splitting bacteria and a common type of bladder stone. Therefore, the statement is true. D. The most common cause of stone formation is distal passage obstruction. True. Distal obstruction of the urinary tract (e.g., due to an enlarged prostate in men or a urethral stricture) is the most common predisposing factor for bladder stone formation. The obstruction prevents the bladder from emptying completely, allowing crystals to form and accumulate.

choices.text: Small stones can be removed per urethra

questions.text: Not true about bladder stones is: (AllMS Nov 2014)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Primary bladder stones are formed in the bladder itself in the absence of any underlying predisposing factor like obstruction or infection. It is common in the pediatric age group patients in the tropical countries and as india is one of the tropical countries bladder stone in pediatric age group of indian population is not a rare finding. Bladder stones can be of two types:- primary bladder stones and secondary bladder stones. Primary bladder stones are formed in bladder in the absence of any predisposing factors like obstruction or UTI. Secondary bladder stones on the other hand are formed in the bladder in the presence of some underlying predisposing factor like bladder outlet obstruction or UTI. Out of these two secondary bladder stone are more common. No matter whether it is a primary or secondary bladder stone. If the size of stone is less than 2 cm it can be subjected to Cystolitholapexy, it is an intervention done via per urethral route , in this we pass lithotrite or a bone crushing instrument into the bladder and crush the bladder stone, the fragments of the crushed stone are then allowed to wash away from the bladder Most of the bladder stones are radiopaque is a true statement

choices.text: Always forms in kidneys and passes down to bladder

questions.text: The following is true about bladder stones: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) No matter whether it is a primary or secondary bladder stone. If the size of stone is less than 2 cm it can be subjected to Cystolitholapexy, it is an intervention done via per urethral route , in this we pass lithotrite or a bone crushing instrument into the bladder and crush the bladder stone, the fragments of the crushed stone are then allowed to wash away from the bladder Primary bladder stones are more common in boys as compared to girls in the pediatric age group in tropical countries. Primary bladder stones are formed in urinary bladder in the absence of any outflow tract obstruction or UTI so it is wrong that all the bladder stones form in kidney and pass down into bladder. Bladder stones are not asymptomatic and cause symptoms like increased frequency and hematuria. They often present with terminal hematuria.

choices.text: High incidence in cereal based diet
Peak incidence in 3 years old children in India
Most common type is ammonium urate or calcium oxalate

questions.text: Which of the following is false regarding endemic bladder stones? (AIIMS Nov 2013)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Primary bladder stones once treated do not recur as the child outgrows the age and there occurs a change in the dietary habits . Bladder stones can be of two types:- primary bladder stones and secondary bladder stones. Primary bladder stones are formed in bladder in the absence of any predisposing factors like obstruction or UTI. Secondary bladder stones on the other hand are formed in the bladder in the presence of some underlying predisposing factor like bladder outlet obstruction or UTI. Out of these two secondary bladder stone are more common. Uric acid stones are the most common cause of the primary bladder calculus. Primary bladder stones are common in pediatric patients in tropics. This is implicated to dietary factors of pediatric patients in tropics which includes predominance of cereal based diet.

choices.text: Posterior urethra rupture, with-retention of urine

questions.text: A person after pelvic fracture could not pass urine. On examination bladder is not palpable. What is probable diagnosis? (LQ
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Bladder rupture are of two types:- extra peritoneal bladder rupture and intra peritoneal bladder rupture. Extra peritoneal bladder rupture is associated with pelvic fracture and is more common as compared to intra peritoneal bladder rupture. Intra peritoneal bladder rupture occurs when patient has a full bladder and suffers an injury with the full distended bladder by a blow in hypogastric region.

choices.text: More common than intraperitoneal bladder rupture
Commonly associated with anterior urethral rupture
Can be managed conservatively without surgical intervention

questions.text: True about extraperitoneal urinary bladder rupture is all except: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Extra peritoneal bladder rupture is associated with pelvic fracture and patient presents with a non palpable bladder and inability to pass the urine. Extra peritoneal bladder rupture is more common as compared to intra peritoneal bladder rupture and is associated with posterior urethral injury. Management of extra peritoneal bladder rupture is Passage of a catheter in the urinary bladder and keeping the catheter in place for 7-10 days this helps in healing the rent in the bladder.

questions.text: Tear-drop bladder is seen in: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) In extra peritoneal bladder rupture we see tear drop sign in cystography. In tuberculosis we see thimble bladder. Hunner’s ulcer are seen as multiple linear ulcers in the dome of the bladder.

questions.text: Carcinoma common in dye industry workers: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Carcinoma bladder is of three histological types:- transitional cell carcinoma, squamous cell carcinoma and adenocarcinoma. Out of these three types transitional cell carcinoma is the most common type and workers who work in dye industry is a risk factor for this.

questions.text: Transitional cell carcinoma can be seen in: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Analgesic nephropathy is a risk factor for transitional cell carcinoma of bladder. Pulmonary infection and myocardial infarction are not associated with bladder cancer.

questions.text: Transitional cell carcinoma of bladder is associated with: (PGI Nov 2015)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A,B,C,E) Transitional cell carcinoma is the most common histological type of bladder cancer and is associated with: Smoking: Most important risk factor for bladder cancer. Schistosomiasis:It predisposes for both transitional cell cancer and squamous cell cancer but more commonly for squamous cell cancer. Naphthylamine also predisposes to transitional cell carcinoma of bladder. Analgesic nephropathy is another risk factor for carcinoma of bladder. Tuberculosis of bladder does not predispose to bladder cancer.

questions.text: Squamous cell tumor of urinary bladder is due to: (PGI Nov 2014)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A,B,C) Squamous cell carcinoma of urinary bladder are caused by the substances which chronically irritate the bladder mucosa. So it is caused by : Stones, Schistosomiasis and chronic cystitis. Adenocarcinoma of bladder also occurs which is seen in the region of persistent urachus/Trigone. Diabetes is not a predisposing factor for bladder cancer.

questions.text: In a survey, many children are examined and were found to have urogenital abnormalities. Which congenital anomaly is associated with increased risk of bladder carcinoma? (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct answer (B) Bladder anomaly which is associated with increased risk of bladder cancer is extrophy of bladder. Medullary sponge kidney, unilateral renal agenesis and double ureter do not predispose to bladder carcinoma.

questions.text: 'Kiss ulcers of the urinary bladder is: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Kiss ulcers of urinary bladder are benign conditions. They represent two ulcers in close proximity to each other near the bladder neck so they are called as a kiss ulcer.

questions.text: Associated with urinary bladder carcinoma are all of the following except: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) HPV infection is not associated with bladder cancer. It is associated with penile cancer. Risk factors of urinary bladder carcinoma: • Men are 2.5 times more likely than women. • Age increases risk; most commonly diagnosed in the eighth decade and is rare in those <50 years of age. • Race: Black people have a lower incidence than that of White people. • Environmental carcinogens, found in urine are the major cause of bladder cancer. • Chronic inflammation of bladder mucosa: Bladder stones, long term catheters and the ova of Schistosoma haematobium(bilharziasis) are implicated in development of squamous cell carcinoma of the bladder. • Smoking is the major cause of bladder cancer: in the developed world. Cigarette smoke contains the carcinogens 4-aminobiphenyl (4-ABP) and 2-naphthylamine which appears to increase urinary carcinogenic exposure of the urothelium. Smokers have a 2 to 5-fold risk compared to that of non-smokers of developing bladder cancer and subsequent recurrences. Estimates suggest that 30–50% of bladder cancer is caused by smoking. Passive exposure to cigarette smoke is also implicated. • Occupational exposure to carcinogens, in particular aromatic hydrocarbons like aniline, is a recognized cause of bladder cancer.

questions.text: A 53-year old male from the middle east presented with hematuria. The urine showed RBCs but no RBC casts. BUN level was normal. cystoscopy revealed an irregular growth on the mucus of the bladder. A biopsy from this growth revealed features of squamous cell carcinoma. The etiology of this condition is most likely linked to: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) This question is basically trying to ask what is the predisposing factor for squamous cell carcinoma of urinary bladder. And the answer is parasitic infection. Among all the causes mentioned in the above options parasitic infection is the one which causes chronic irritation and leads to the formation of squamous cell carcinoma. Option A is wrong as smoking is an important risk factor transitional cell carcinoma and not squamous cell carcinoma. Option B is wrong as HPV infection is not a risk factor bladder cancer. Option D is wrong as alcohol consumption does not predispose the patient for bladder cancer.

questions.text: SCC of bladder is best treated by: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Treatment of choice for bladder cancer is radical cystectomy. Chemotherapy and radiotherapy are used as an adjuvant treatment options. TURBT is used for the diagnosis of bladder cancer rather than a sole treatment option.

questions.text: Most common tumor of urinary bladder is: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Benign tumors of the bladder, including inverted papilloma and nephrogenic adenoma, are uncommon. The vast majority of primary bladder cancers are malignant and epithelial in origin. • >90% are transitional cell carcinoma (TCC); urothelial carcinoma (UC) is now the preferred term. • 1–7% are squamous cell carcinoma (SCC). • 75% are SCC in areas where schistosomiasis is endemic. • 2% are adenocarcinoma. • Rarities include pheochromocytoma, melanoma, lymphoma, and sarcoma arising within the bladder muscle. • Secondary bladder cancers are mostly metastatic adenocarcinoma from gut, prostate, kidney, or ovary.

questions.text: Bladder tumors mostly arises from: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Most of the bladder cancers are transitional cell carcinoma and they arise from the mucosal lining of the bladder which is comprising of transitional cells.

questions.text: Most constant and persistent feature of CA bladder is: (PGI May 2014)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) most of the patients of bladder cancer come with gross painless hematuria as a presenting feature. Other three can also be present in bladder cancer but the most constant and persistant finding is hematuria.

choices.text: Endoscopic tumor resection and intravesical chemotherapy
Radical cystectomy with or without radiotherapy

questions.text: Treatment of choice for bladder pTa: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) If the stage of the tumour would have been pTa(pathological Ta) then TURBT would just have been enough. If the stage of the tumour would have been pT1 then we would have given intravesical BCG as chemotherapy for the treatment. If bladder tumour is a deep tumour (muscle invasive tumour) we have to subject the patient to total cystectomy plus as lymph nodes are enlarged we have to do pelvic lymphadenectomy. Systemic chemotherapy is an adjuvant treatment option and not the main stay of the treatment.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most effective intravesical therapy for superficial bladder cancer? (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Out of all the agents used for intravescical therapy, intra vesical BCG is the most effective treatment option. Bacillus-Calmette–Guérin (BCG) is an attenuated strain of Mycobacterium bovis. It acts as an immune stimulant, up-regulating cytokines such as IL-6 and IL-8 in the bladder wall. BCG is given as a 6-week course,starting at least 2 weeks post-TURBT.

questions.text: Urinary incontinence results from all except: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Rectovesical fistula doesn’t cause urinary incontinence, as the level of fistula is above the sphincter mechanism.

questions.text: To differentiate between stress incontinence and detrusor instability investigation done is: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Cystometric studies are urodynamic studies in which the pressure changes in the bladder is simultaneously measured with bladder flling and during micturition. It helps in accurate assessment of detrusor and sphincter activity especially if a neurogenic abnormality is suspected. Option C that is MCU is done do look for bladder and posterior urethral pathologies. Option A and D are used for looking at the anatomical structures and variations in the lumen of the urethra.

questions.text: A patient, Ramu presents with hematuria for many days. On investigations he is found to have renal calculi, calcifications in the wall of urinary bladder and small contracted bladder; most probable cause is: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Most common cause of bladder calcification is schistosomiasis. Schistosomiasis can also involve the kidney and lead to renal calculi too. Option B amyloidosis is not a cause of bladder calculi Option C that is tuberculosis does lead to small contracted bladder known as thimble bladder but it does not cause bladder calcification. Option D Carcinoma of urinary bladder can lead to hematuria but it does not lead to small contracted bladder.

questions.text: One of the following disease will show urinary bladder calcification radiologicaly which resembles fetal head in pelvis: (AIIMS May 2015)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) X-ray appearance of schistosomiasis is fetal head in pelvis appearance. Option B Tuberculosis when affects kidney it shows up as a putty kidney and when it affects urinary bladder it will show up as thimble bladder and won’t show as a calcification. Option C that is chronic cystitis does not lead to calcification in the urinary bladder. Option D is malignancy and malignancy of urinary bladder does not show up as calcification of the bladder.

questions.text: Metrifonate is effective against: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Drug treatment for Schistosomiasis consists of 3 drugs. The can be remembered by the mnemonic MOP which stands for:- M: Metrifonate O: Oxaminiquine P: Praziquintal. So answer here is option C as we use metrifonate for the treatment of schistosomiasis.

choices.text: Heavily sedate and paralyze the patient. Repeat bladder pressure.
Heavily sedate the patient. Repeat the bladder pressure the following day
Perform a decompressive laparotomy with a temporary abdominal closure

questions.text: A 65-year-old obese man undergoes emergent aortic aneurysm repair. He requires large-volume resuscitation due to the long operative time. After surgery, he develops rhabdomyolysis, oliguria, and volume overload. His abdomen becomes distended. An abdominal x-ray reveals a gas pattern consistent with ileus; there is mildly dilated small bowel with a paucity of gas in the colon. Although his vitals are stable, tenderness is illicited on examination of abdomen. Bladder pressure is measured to be 22 mmHg. What is the appropriate next step?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) This patient has developed abdominal compartment syndrome (ACS). During large-volume resuscitation associated with an inflammatory response, capillary leak leads to edema of the abdominal wall and intestine. The abdominal wall becomes less compliant, the intestines swell, and ascites production ensues. The resulting intraabdominal hypertension results in decreased abdominal organ perfusion by occluding capillaries and veins. Oliguria heralds acute renal failure. To diagnose ACS, bladder pressure should be measured in a supine patient who is placed in a flat position. Pressures less than20 mmHg are reassuring. However, for pressures exceeding 20mmHg, the measurement must be repeated in the setting of paralysis,which removes external forces contributing to abdominal hypertension. In the setting of heavy sedation and paralysis,pressures exceeding 20 mmHg warrant further investigation.
